title: 113_hr541
content: The Act is known as the "PREEMIE Reauthorization Act" and focuses on research and activities at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The PREEMIE Reauthorization Act amends Section 3 to allow the Secretary of Health and Human Services to conduct epidemiological studies on factors related to prematurity, improve national data tracking, and continue efforts to prevent preterm birth. The PREEMIE Reauthorization Act aims to prevent preterm birth, including late preterm birth, by identifying prevention opportunities and assessing the impact of these efforts. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit reports to Congress every 2 years on the progress and results of studies conducted. The Act also updates the time frame for the Prematurity Research Expansion and Education for Mothers who deliver Infants Early Act from "2007 through 2011" to "2014 through 2018." The Secretary of Health and Human Services is required to submit reports to Congress every 2 years on the progress of studies. The Act also extends the time frame for the Prematurity Research Expansion and Education for Mothers who deliver Infants Early Act from "2007 through 2011" to "2014 through 2018." The PREEMIE Reauthorization Act focuses on preventing preterm birth and assessing prevention efforts. It amends sections of the Public Health Service Act related to telemedicine, high-risk pregnancies, and public health education. Amendments include adding prenatal care for high-risk pregnancies and core risk factors for preterm labor. The PREEMIE Reauthorization Act focuses on preventing preterm birth and assessing prevention efforts, including weight maintenance, good nutrition, screening for infections, stress management, treatments for premature infants, informational needs of families in neonatal care units, and evidence-based strategies to prevent birth injuries. It also includes programs to increase availability of pregnancy and post-term information services. The PREEMIE Reauthorization Act aims to provide evidence-based clinical information on causes of prematurity, birth defects, and health risks to post-term infants through various means. Additionally, it updates the time frame for subsection (c) from "2007 through 2011" to "2014 through 2018." SEC. 4. OTHER ACTIVITIES. The Prematurity Research Expansion and Education for Mothers who deliver Infants Early Act is amended by removing section 5. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may establish an Advisory Committee on Infant Mortality to provide advice on reducing infant mortality and improving the health of pregnant women and infants. The Advisory Committee on Infant Mortality aims to reduce preterm birth rates and coordinate federal, state, and local programs to improve the health of pregnant women and infants. They will implement the Healthy Start program and work towards Healthy People 2020 infant mortality objectives. The Advisory Committee on Infant Mortality will develop a plan for research and education on preterm birth through the Department of Health and Human Services. The plan will examine activities receiving Federal funding to reduce preterm birth rates and address disparities. It will also identify research gaps and implement evidence-based strategies. The Secretary will ensure that the Advisory Committee on Infant Mortality includes representatives from the original charter and the National Center for Health Statistics. An agency will coordinate studies on hospital readmissions of preterm infants. The agency designated under the Act will submit a report to the Secretary and Congress within a year, containing findings and recommendations on reducing preventable hospital readmissions for preterm infants.
